nexttext: The first $SU(2)$ factor is a remnant of the conformal group, broken by the presence of the latitude circle. This is, in fact, the same $SU(2)$ factor from $SO(4,2)$ which is also preserved by the 1/2 BPS circle, although the symmetry is realized differently in the two cases. Note, in passing, that the 1/4 BPS loop does not preserve the $SL(2,\mathbb{R})$ subgroup of $SO(4,2)$ preserved by the 1/2 BPS circle. In the holographic dual, this will manifest itself in the fact that the induced metric on the string world-sheet is not $AdS_2$, as it is the case for the string corresponding to the 1/2 BPS circle. The  $U(1)$ symmetry in (\ref{symmetries}) mixes Lorentz and R-symmetry transformations
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="SU(2)\times U(1)\times SU(2)_{B}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>U</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>×</mo><mi>U</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>×</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>U</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>B</mi></msub></mpadded></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: The first $SU(2)$ factor is a remnant of the conformal group, broken by the presence of the latitude circle. This is, in fact, the same $SU(2)$ factor from $SO(4,2)$ which is also preserved by the 1/2 BPS circle, although the symmetry is realized differently in the two cases. Note, in passing, that the 1/4 BPS loop does not preserve the $SL(2,\mathbb{R})$ subgroup of $SO(4,2)$ preserved by the 1/2 BPS circle. In the holographic dual, this will manifest itself in the fact that the induced metric on the string world-sheet is not $AdS_2$, as it is the case for the string corresponding to the 1/2 BPS circle. The  $U(1)$ symmetry in (\ref{symmetries}) mixes Lorentz and R-symmetry transformations

nexttext:
One explicitly sees that there is an $SO(3)$ group that rotates the coordinates  $(X_3,X_4,X_5)$ without affecting the solution.
On the $S^5$ side, whose equation we write as $Y_1^2+Y_2^2+Y_3^2+Y_4^2+Y_5^2+Y_6^2=1$, we have

nexttext:
The second term in (\ref{sum789}) is what will give the predicted result (\ref{prediction}) from the gauge theory. It comes from the $E=0$ mode of the $\Omega^{7,8,9}_E$ determinant.

It can be easily checked that the small $\epsilon_0$ and large $\Lambda$ limits commute for the bosonic determinants. In fact, we have already set $\epsilon_0=0$ in the result above. For large $\Lambda$, one obtains a logarithmic divergence
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\cal F}(\sigma_{0},\Lambda)\equiv\frac{\Gamma\left(\Lambda+1+\tanh\sigma_{0}%
\right)}{\Gamma\left(\Lambda+2\right)\Gamma\left(1+\tanh\sigma_{0}\right)}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℱ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≡</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>tanh</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>tanh</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mpadded></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
The second term in (\ref{sum789}) is what will give the predicted result (\ref{prediction}) from the gauge theory. It comes from the $E=0$ mode of the $\Omega^{7,8,9}_E$ determinant.

It can be easily checked that the small $\epsilon_0$ and large $\Lambda$ limits commute for the bosonic determinants. In fact, we have already set $\epsilon_0=0$ in the result above. For large $\Lambda$, one obtains a logarithmic divergence
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\ln{\cal F}(\sigma_{0},\Lambda)=\left(\tanh\sigma_{0}-1\right)\ln\Lambda-\ln%
\Gamma\left(1+\tanh\sigma_{0}\right)+{\cal O}(\Lambda^{-1})\,," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℱ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>tanh</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>tanh</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒪</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\sum_{E\in\mathbb{Z}}\Omega^{5,6}_{E}\longrightarrow\sum_{E=-\Lambda-1}^{%
\Lambda}\Omega^{5,6}_{E}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>ℤ</mi></mrow></munder><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>E</mi><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mo>⟶</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi></munderover><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>E</mi><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msubsup></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
